title: Do you think Biden can beat Trump? - Quora
tags: Politics of the United States of America

response.answer_text: Maybe.  Here is the latest survey. It tells us where things are. (Note to foreigners: Trump is Republican/red, and Biden is Democrat/blue). Believe it or not Texas is now a swing state. Over the last few years, hundreds of thousands of Democrats have been moving to Texas from California and this new influx in population makes the state a close race. Ohio and Georgia also remain toss-up states. If Trump loses any of these states, the election is lost. Beyond that, you can see that the Democrats pretty safely have 248 electoral votes going into this election. This places them 22 votes away from a win. Trump needs a whole 66 electoral votes to secure victory. Right now we have these states up for grab ArizonaWisconsinPennsylvaniaNorth CarolinaFloridaIf Trump losses Florida, he losses the election. Besides Florida Trump can only lose 1 swing state and must win all the rest. If Trump losses 2 swing states, he loses the election. So now I am going to update the map with 3 things. Florida: Trump. The Republican governor of Florida is very popular and is a big Trump supporter. The state is older in terms of population and tends to vote right. Given the popularity of the governor and the state’s Senators I find it HIGHLY unlikely that Trump will lose Florida.Wisconsin: Biden. Wisconsin voted for Trump in 2016. This is an extremely rare move for a traditionally Democrat state. Since then Republican Senators, congressmen, and governors have been ousted by Democratic challengers. This seems to be a pretty clear indication that the Democratic has reasserted itself as the dominant party in the state.Arizona: Trump. In 2018 the Republican governor Doug Ducey was reelected and won the election by a big margin. Since then the state remains just as strongly Republican as in 2020.So in my estimation here is what we are looking at, guaranteed.  It really comes down to North Carolina and Pennsylvania. Trump has to win both states to win the election and Biden only needs to win 1. So if Biden does better than Trump in these states he wins. That is really what it comes down to. Now with these states, it is going to be tough. Really there is a lot to be seen here and its hard to say how this will go. Some big factors are COVID response: A lot of what will happen will come down to how the public views Trump’s COVID response. To many Democrats, Trump’s response was a total failure and they may be right. To many Republicans, Trump’s response was measured and successful and they may be right. We are going to have to see what independent voters and undecided voters think. Also, please don’t go into the comments and be mean to each other. We are allowed to disagree and still treat each other with respect. The media is mostly liberal-leaning and social media has shown a proclivity to advertise particular positions that they support. So in a sense, Trump is facing an uphill battle in this regard. That being said I know among many blue-collar voters there has been a strong desire to re-open. The economy was booming under Trump for the last 3 years and many want to get back to how things were going before. Blue-collar voters tend to decide elections. Had it not been for COVID I would be placing my money on Trump winning. Presidents that preside over strong economies tend to get reelected. COVID has really thrown a wrench into the works though and it has made everything unpredictable. I think this issue favors Biden in the long run as his hands are clean of the whole mess. Biden Campaign: I am not a Russian bot. I understand discussing this may upset people who support Biden but we need to openly and honestly discuss him as a candidate. This question is about Biden, not Trump. Had it been about Trump I would be discussing his flaws and issues as well. I am going to catch a lot of flak for this but hear me out. Biden has so far had a rather poor showing. The nation is in crisis and he seems to be invisible, unwilling to comment on anything. When he does comment nobody seems to really care very much. Many of his public appearances were gaff filled confusing affairs. He has looked confused and walked off-camera, he has mistaken his wife for his sister, and he has cited the wrong numbers when discussing statistics. The constant claims of “cognitive decline” remains unsubstantiated but prevalent none the less. You may see me discussing this as being anti-Biden but that is not the case. When I look up Biden on Tiktok or Youtube it mostly memes making fun of him. In addition, he now has a sexual assault allegation against him. I am not sure if it is true or not. If I say I believe Tara than I get flak for being alt-right but if I don’t believe Tara I am anti-MeToo. Personally, though I don’t see enough evidence to think he did it. Democrats are in a hard place here. They tried to remove Judge Kavanaugh from his spot on the supreme court when similar allegations emerged. If the party ignores the allegations they look bad to progressives and look hypocritical, if they don’t they look bad to everyone else. It also removes some of the moral high ground. Trump has multiple sexual assault allegations against him that could be used as leverage but with Biden being in a similar (but smaller) boat it removes this as an option. Unless you want the slogan “I allegedly assaulted fewer women”. All that being said Biden is not necessarily a bad pick at all for the spot. He is the opposite of Trump in a lot of ways. Where Trump is rather rough and uncouth Biden is far more charming and polished. Where Trump is aggressive and dominating, Biden is calm and relaxed. Biden is the a-typical Presidential candidate. If you put out a call for an actor to play the President in a movie, you’d get Biden. A lot of people may be tired of the drama around Trump and go with Biden because Biden is a safe familiar candidate. At the same time though Biden is rather unexciting. I don’t see much buzz around his ideas or the changes he will make. He is running on the “I’m not Trump platform” which may not work. He needs to generate buzz and he needs to get people excited about him. Trump is great at this and Biden will need to compete. Biden could find a great VP and run an awesome campaign and win. But if his performance so far is an accurate indication of what is to come he may fail miserably. Only time will tell. Economic recovery: If the economy can recover a good bit before November Trump will likely win. People are afraid and concerned about their livelihoods. Coming off a period of instability and fear people may stick to Trump if that means maintaining a recovering economy. This may not reflect the situation accurately, in that Trump may not be responsible for a recovering economy but none the less it will be a factor to consider. George Floyd: This is another big issue in the context of “defunding police”. This is a wildly unpopular position right now among every demographic. If this position is adopted by Biden he may lose of a lot of moderate support. My prediction: I can’t say for sure who I honestly think will win. There are just too many factors that remain unknown. How will Biden run his campaign? Who will make a serious mistake? What big pieces of negative information will come out about the candidates? Will the economy recover? Will COVID get worse? To be totally honest I think that right now Biden is likely to win. Statistically, Trump has to win North Carolina, Pennsylvania, and Florida to win. These are all close races that are going to come down to a few thousand votes. Statistically speaking Biden has a great shot at winning simply because he only has to do well in 1 of these states where Trump needs to go great in all 3. Also, COVID was a rotten bit of luck for Trump. Disregarding the whole conversation about how well or poorly the federal government responded to the crisis it killed the economy. Traditionally strong economies get candidates re-elected while weak economies allow challengers to win. Going into 2020 the US economy was surging to record levels as the DOW neared 30,000 and unemployment dropped to below 3%. COVID turned the economy on it’s head and shook things up drastically. The US media is very biased on both directions and I see no world where Trump isn’t blamed for every single COVID death by large segments of the media. In other words unless the economy magically rebounds tomorrow and we cure COVID the day after I don’t see Trump winning in 2020. I have one more twist here, hear me out. This may sound like Alex Jones stuff but hear me out. I have this intuition or feeling that this will be the case. If I am right people can come back here and give me credit- because I think I am right. I don’t think Biden will be running for office come November. The DNC really wants to beat Trump and they have not been above shady practices in the past. I think Biden got Sanders out of the way because the DNC knew Sanders would never win. It was all rather sudden because for quite a while it seemed like Sanders was gonna win, then in the last mile, Biden jumped way out ahead. But Biden has baggage. The guy has given people dozens of horrible memes and soundbites (you ain’t black) and he is hardly on TV. When Biden is being interviewed every day do you think it will be better? The DNC has to know this. I think right after Biden is given the nod to run we will see a sudden focus on Tara’s allegations and past mistakes. Popular Democrats will call for Biden to step down and somebody else, handpicked by the party will get the nod. This is 100% my opinion backed by nothing substantial though. Although as a commenter John Anderson below pointed out, and as I confirmed, Biden has yet to establish a presence in states like Wisconsin. He has not hired anyone to run his campaign in that state which is very strange. The election is only a few months out and Trump has been targeting these states for years. It is really odd for a candidate to not be investing in swing states in late June. I just wanted to put it here in case I am right. I am likely wrong but I just have this gut feeling that before too long Biden will be stepping down to make way for his VP pick or for Cuomo. If I am right, make sure to come back and make me internet famous! If I am wrong I will fully admit it.

What makes Biden a better candidate than Trump? Literally everything. For a moment, let’s pretend it’s 2016 and it’s Trump vs. Biden with an outgoing Obama administration. Now one choice is a man with no government experience, with a history of failed marriages and failed businesses, who was born rich and went bankrupt because he couldn’t figure out how to turn a profit with a casino. A man who keeps saying he has big plans but offers no substance. A man who bullies his detractors and whose campaign was built on attacking people of color, including the President, who he spent years accusing of forging his birth certificate. The other choice is a man who has spent nearly half a century in public service. He knows how government works. He has good working relationships with leaders of both parties and with our allies. He served in the administration that saved the American auto industry, successfully navigated two epidemics, brought the economy back from the brink of a second Great Depression, killed Public Enemy Number One Osama bin Laden, and despite obstruction and false accusations from the opposition party, secured healthcare for 15 million uninsured Americans and did it all without a single indictment of any member of the administration. A man whose only Achilles heel is that he famously misspeaks often. So now let’s move forward four years. Biden still puts his foot in his mouth, but the only thing that has actually changed is now we know that Trump can’t handle the job. Before the coronavirus pandemic he had flatlined a growing economy, been impeached for abusing his office, had been found to have committed ten distinct acts of obstruction of justice to cover up his illegal coordination with Russian interference in the 2016 election, he set a record for public lies by a sitting President, spent 300 years of Presidential salaries on golf trips—with much of that money going back into his own pockets, almost triggered world war three, doubled the deficit, bankrupted American farmers and businesses with his ill-advised trade war, and set a record for indictments, guilty pleas, and convictions by members of an administration. Then he mishandled the coronavirus pandemic and 100,000 Americans died, unemployment more than tripled, and the deficit went up tenfold. And now America is on fire and he’s literally hiding in the White House with the lights turned off. In fairness he did tear gas some peaceful protesters yesterday so he could leave the White House for a photo op, but I don’t think pointing that out helps him. That’s the choice. Competency and integrity, or four more years of a dumpster fire.

He certainly can. That doesn't mean he will, but it's looking good for him at this moment. A lot can happen in two months. If, by some miracle of miracles, the United States can fully develop an effective COVID-19 vaccine prior to the election, turn out the lights, because it's four more years of Trump. I would be enormously shocked if we can pull that one off. If, again, by some miracle of miracles we can successfully get the kids back to school full time without cases spiking, same deal. But, sorry, that's not going to happen. If somehow the Trump campaign can find some dirt to definitively prove Joe Biden has done something completely unforgivable (sexual assault, etc.), then that definitely will take the wind out of his sails. Not beyond the realm of possibility, but I have strong doubts. What can help Joe Biden are strong performances at the debates by him against Donald Trump, and Kamala Harris against Mike Pence. Joe can hold his own, but he has to be able to play the game that The Donald is going to play. You know, the constant interruptions, the childish nicknames and put downs, brooding about the stage, etc. I think he's more prepared to deal with that effectively than Hillary was. The Pence-Harris debate, though, is going to be electric!! I don't agree with very much of what Mr. Pence has to say, but he is a skilled debater. Mrs. Harris is, too, and she knows how to drive a point home, with an exclamation point. It's going to be sick. And, who knows if some October Surprise could come and bite The Donald in the rear? If COVID-19 sees a resurgence, if he and the Feds botch a natural disaster response (again!), if unemployment gets worse, if he exacerbates relations with a foreign power, etc. Right now, Joe Biden has held a consistent lead both nationally and in all the important swing states. Things are starting to tighten, so neither major candidate has this “in the bag” yet. The next few weeks are going to be crucial. Whomever you're planning to vote for, please, be safe at the polls, or else request your absentee ballot and submit it as early as you are permitted. See y'all at the polls!!

(Full disclosure: I am a Conservative and will likely be voting for Trump in the next election. To the best of my ability though, this is an attempt at an apolitical description of Biden’s chances against Trump, as an electoral game of tactics.) Yes, so long as the election is a referendum on Trump and not Biden. One of the key factors behind 2016 was that the American electorate focused more on their distaste for Clinton as a candidate, than Trump’s qualifications for the same position. In 2020, the picture will be at least partially reversed: Trump will have his own record in politics to defend, which reduces some of the appeal that he carried as an outsider when he first ran for office. The only problem is that Joe Biden has a lengthy record himself, and his ability to defend it is hampered by the general leftward drift of the Democratic Party relative to himself. While the moderates within the Democratic Party were able to overwhelm the hard Progressive wing headed by Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren, they cannot afford to ignore them entirely and still have a prayer of maintaining a cohesive base which can carry Biden through the General Election. By that same token, if Biden strays too far into the hard Progressive camp, he risks alienating the general American populace. This risk is especially present with regards to the tearing down of statues of famous figures in American history, which will likely be upsetting to those not too ensconced in politics. The solution from the Democratic side is obvious. Stay quiet, and let all of the national attention fixate on Trump, and pray that he detonates his re-election chances himself. Considering his lack of discipline when it comes to his public rhetoric, that could very well work. However, this also carries dangers. For one, it risks giving Trump the initiative to determine the conversation. While most news media outlets are supportive of the Democrats, they cannot help but play off of Trump to drive viewer engagement, which gives Trump the advantage in terms of picking topics. The 2016 elections were not initially focused on immigration until Trump entered the scene with divisive (and therefore widely discussed) comments on illegal immigration across the Mexican border. And for another, it could expose Biden to negative public attention rather than mitigate it. The game of democratic politics is the game of making easier to vote for you, as supposed to voting for the other guy. Trump is excellent at this, insofar as it relates to poisoning the public perceptions of his opposition. From his surprise victories in the Republican primaries, to the General Election itself, he consistently displayed talent at re-framing his opponents in unflattering ways in the eyes of the public. The more public attention Trump is allowed to hoard for himself, the more opportunities he has to disrupt Biden’s public image. Considering the latter’s decades in politics, it is unlikely Trump will lack for material on this front, some of it brought front and center by Biden’s former primary opponents. When it comes to debates, Biden is going to have a harder time defending himself than when he ran as Obama’s VP, due to the balancing act that he has to play with his own party, which (at least to my eyes) seems much more fractured than the Republican base. This highlights the issue of Joe Biden’s capacity. I watched all of the Democratic primary debates. He is not as rhetorically sharp as he used to be, and that will hurt his public image in the eyes of voters, and could inflame concerns regarding his mental health and fitness. In fact, it may be more practical for the Biden campaign to dispense with the debates in order to avoid just such a scenario, citing concerns over the pandemic. Trump will slam him for it, of course, but that can be justified to Biden’s own base as Trump simply not caring enough about the virus. It would not be a costless strategy, but neither is participating in the debates. If Biden maintains his current lead in the polls, I would definitely be pushing for that if I was Biden’s campaign strategist. However, just because Trump won the last time using this method does not mean he will win again. Biden is a much less disliked candidate than Clinton was, and as such has a lot more flexibility when it comes to how he can respond to Trump’s attacks. Additionally, Trump as the incumbent will be held responsible by the American people generally for the overall status of the United States. If there is no V-shaped economic recovery, and/or if Trump’s administration is regarded as having failed to have dealt with the current pandemic, his base may not be energized and his re-election may be in jeopardy. If Trump cannot persuade the American people that his re-election will guarantee future stability and prosperity (or at the very least, that Joe Biden will not) his paths to victory are limited, and I think we are seeing that sentiment in the latest poll numbers. Ultimately, once candidates get to the national level, there is almost always the potential for victory from either party. Sometimes events beyond the candidates control work against them (economic troubles, social upheaval, etc.), and sometimes the candidates themselves do something unabashedly stupid which saps their base of support. A lot can change over the course of a few days, never mind several months.

In my humble opinion, no. First, the statistics aren't in his favor: Only two former Vice Presidents have ever run for President — Richard Nixon in 1968 and Walter Mondale in 1984. Nixon won a three-way race, with 43% of the vote; Mondale ran against a popular incumbent.The polls showing him leading Bernie Sanders by double digits are suspect, at best. There are very few Millennials with land lines these days. While Gallup has been including cell phone users in its polling since 2008, the same cannot be said for other polling organizations. Including cell phone users in a poll is more expensive and requires the human element (as opposed to robo-callers). So, the jury is still out on just how much these polls can be relied upon.So much for the registered Democrats. I'm not one of those people who blames the DNC and “the establishment” to the exclusion of all else. On the contrary, I blame the voters as well, and one of my biggest beefs is against the registered Democratic voters who are so willfully myopic that they cannot see that it is not only their opinion that counts. If you're trying to sell a candidate to the whole nation, it makes sense to properly gauge what the voters want (not to presume to know what they want) and elect in the primaries a candidate that is going to appeal across as broad a spectrum as possible. I'm especially vehement on this point because those voters who consistently support the establishment center-right candidates continue to dig their heels into the ground with protests of “It's our party!” and “Never Bernie!” when there is no good reason to do so. A progressive candidate, be it Bernie Sanders or someone else, stands for all the things they claim to want. Their only reason for opposing that candidate is because they feel that what he/she wants is “not realistic". The reality of today's political landscape is that 44% of the registered voters in the U.S. are registered Independents, the largest percentage of such in living memory. Also, the Millennials are on the fast track to becoming the largest age group voting bloc in the country, and they are overwhelmingly progressive in their politics. Bernie Sanders is the most popular politician in the country, and given how very difficult it is to beat an incumbent President running for re-election, the Democrats had better nominate a rock star to run in 2020, or we're going to have four more years of Trump. So, no, Biden doesn't have a chance of beating Trump. He just won't excite the Independents and the Millennials, because those groups will want to know what he brings to the table (his “Give me a break!” statement about the Millennials will work decisively against him with that group). And the answer is that he doesn't offer anything of substance or any new ideas, only “Oh my God, Trump is horrible!”, and that's a recipe for an election night loss. Update, 17 July 2020: I answered this question last year in June, in the context of the pre-primary debates. My answer would be very different today. It’s not so much about people voting for Biden as it is against Trump. We haven't had a presidential election like this one for a long time, and it's going to get mighty interesting.

Investigations Continue To Turn Up More Trump And Russia Ties Less than four months into his presidency, Trump fired FBI Director Comey because of “this Russia thing with Trump,” leading to the appointment of Special Counsel Robert Mueller. As the special counsel’s investigation continues to get to the bottom of links between the Trump campaign and Russia — and hold Trump’s cronies responsible for their crimes — it is essential the investigation be protected from Trump’s interference. Trump asked then-FBI Director James Comey to drop a federal investigation into Trump’s former National Security Adviser Michael Flynn. Trump fired FBI Director Comey, admitting shortly afterward that he did so because of the Russia investigation. Mueller’s investigation has resulted in more than 100 criminal counts, 33 people and three companies charged, and guilty pleas from five Trump associates — so far. Trump’s longtime personal lawyer and fixer, Michael Cohen, pleaded guilty to lying to Congress about the timeline of the Trump Tower Moscow project in order to protect Trump. Trump’s former National Security Adviser Michael Flynn pleaded guilty to lying to the FBI and agreed to cooperate with the special counsel’s investigation. Trump’s former campaign chairman, Paul Manafort, was convicted at trial on eight counts related to money laundering. The next month, he pleaded guilty to two more counts in a separate trial and agreed to cooperate with the special counsel’s investigation (Mueller’s office subsequently revoked the plea deal because Manafort wouldn’t stop lying). Trump’s former deputy campaign chairman and Manafort’s longtime business partner, Rick Gates, pleaded guilty to two charges and agreed to cooperate with the special counsel’s investigation. Trump campaign foreign policy adviser George Papadopoulos pleaded guilty to lying to the FBI about his interactions with Russians. Trump publicly emerged at the center of Mueller’s investigation after being labeled “Individual 1” in criminal filings, suggesting that Trump continues to be a major subject of interest in the probe. Despite Trump’s frequent denials during the 2016 presidential campaign that he had any business deals in Russia, negotiations for Trump Tower Moscow continued until June 2016, well into the campaign. Trump discussed the project on multiple occasions with Michael Cohen, and Trump family members received briefings. Michael Cohen spoke with the Kremlin about the project, and the Trump Organization even planned to give Vladimir Putin a penthouse apartment in the finished tower. Nearly Everything Trump Has Ever Run Is Under Investigation Trump has a decades-long history of acting as if he were above the law. In addition to the special counsel’s investigation, Trump and organizations he has run have been the subjects of fraud and corruption investigations by federal and state prosecutors, as well as party to lawsuits alleging that Trump is violating the Constitution by accepting bribe money from foreign nations. Trump was personally implicated in a hush-money scheme during the 2016 election to silence two women that alleged they had affairs with him. Trump Organization CFO Allen Weisselberg was granted immunity by federal prosecutors to testify about Michael Cohen before a grand jury, giving prosecutors access to his unparalleled knowledge of Trump’s finances. Federal prosecutors were probing whether Trump’s inauguration misspent funds or accepted contributions in exchange for favors that run afoul of federal corruption laws. New York State authorities opened a probe into Trump’s company following a bombshell report detailing decades of tax fraud. Civil lawsuits alleging Trump is violating the Constitution’s emoluments clause put the Trump Organization’s financial records under fire. The Trump Foundation was forced to dissolve as part of an ongoing investigation by the New York Attorney General’s office into Trump’s years-long use of the foundation for his own benefit.

I have always respected Joe Biden for his well-intentioned and bipartisan approach to politics. But although the President’s flaws are very well chronicled, I think there are many reasons that Biden might not be able to beat him. Many of the President’s critics talk about how “dumb” he is. He certainly is not the most gifted in an intellectual sense, but he is absolutely brilliant in all of the ways in which most of us would hope a leader wouldn’t be. He is unconstrained by traditional rules of conduct, scruples or ethics, and he has an innate grasp of political showmanship. He is careful to project forcefulness, especially in situations where it is most unnecessary to do so (such as press briefings). In a distinctive way he is the most media-savvy President since Ronald Reagan, and this understanding enables him to control virtually any situation in front of a camera. And his lack of intellectual curiosity can give him a peculiar yet particular confidence derived from having no perceived need to question any of his thoughts. For better or worse, he is an adept salesman. These characteristics present a malevolent yet challenging skill set for an opposing candidate to counteract. We are seeing the results of this during the current pandemic. Despite a litany of well-chronicled misstatements as the pandemic began, a large portion of the country is now convinced that 83,000 deaths in two months is a “success story.” He is encouraging the country to reopen despite a still-increasing curve of cases in many states, bolstered by his ability to act as though the virus is already behind us. He introduced “Operation Warp Speed,” an effort to sell the notion of a vaccine within six months, when most scientists believe it will take a year or more. And in a short space of a couple of minutes he asserted “the vaccine will be ready,” “not everyone will want a vaccine,” “we might not need a vaccine if the virus disappears,” and “with or without a vaccine, we’re back.” His supporters therefore have the option of picking and choosing from a vast menu of things they might really want to hear. And these statements, combined with the attributes I described earlier, have created an unshakable devotion provided by his adoring base. For those of us who are accustomed to the polished communication skills and logical, predictable thought processes of prior leaders, we might wonder what propelled him to the Presidency. But for his supporters, his approach is absolutely intoxicating and generates tremendous amounts of loyalty. This is a large part of the reason that many of the President’s supporters believe him over experts such as Dr. Anthony Fauci, who is one of the nation’s most revered and credentialed public health experts. And a contributing factor is that some of these supporters would probably question the value of “experts” anyway, even during a pandemic. Despite an abysmal response to the pandemic and a sudden, Depression-level economy, the President continues to generate a visceral, emotional reaction that serves him well. And because of his lack of character-related constraints, he might have a variety of cunning upcoming tactics at his disposal that the Biden campaign has not even considered. Therefore the Democratic Party needs to be aware that any traditional “rules” under which it is operating might not be acknowledged, or could even be repudiated, by the President. For all of these reasons, the President remains a formidable candidate and incumbent. The Democratic Party underestimates him at their peril.

I really don’t know. No one else does, either. Here’s the thing, though: we now have incontrovertible proof of what happens when you sit out the election because your preferred candidate didn’t get the nomination. I expect Democrats to go very hard on the message of supporting whoever won the nomination. Biden’s numbers have shrunk somewhat, but a he retains a base of support that is not much more likely to be moved by his gaffes than Trump voters were moved by his talk of grabbing women by their private parts. (“Take him seriously, but don’t take him literally…!”) Biden is likely to put in a mediocre showing in Iowa and New Hampshire, then crush it in South Carolina. His supporters will take this as evidence that he can go the distance. I don’t think Biden’s chances of beating Trump have much to do with his gaffes or even whether there are questions about his faculties. Firstly and assuming that he wins the nomination (not a foregone conclusion), he has to pick the right running mate. His pick has to reassure the voters that someone they would want to have as acting POTUS is waiting in the number two slot if age catches up with Biden during his term. I think this person is Kamala Harris, but I’m open to arguments about other candidates. Provided he makes the right choice, any concerns voters may have about Biden’s age will be greatly diminished. Secondly, Biden simply has to keep reminding voters of everything that has turned out sourly during the Trump Administration. Between tweets, farming losses, the costs of the trade war, and his refusal to abide by separation of powers, there’s plenty of material to choose from. Biden’s target audience isn’t going to be people who stopped watching Fox because Fox got too liberal. He’s going to be after the Obama-Trump voters. That’s who he needs. These are people who don’t care what the Dow Jones is doing because there’s nothing in the Dow Jones for them. These are people who will have noticed that their staples from China are more expensive than they used to be. These are people who will have noticed that manufacturing is shedding jobs in key states in direct response to the trade war. They voted for Trump to change things up, and a lot of them are no better off for it. Content that their voices have been heard at last, they can afford to be receptive to the message that Trump had the right idea about fixing the trade problem with China but that a Biden Administration will address the problem with due concern for the well-being of the average American wage earner. Of course, we don’t know that Biden will even get the nomination. Super Tuesday will tell us a lot more. Until then, it’s a lot of guesswork.

We cannot know with certainty until at least the night of November 3rd 2020. At this time it’s still more likely than Trump winning reelection. That doesn’t mean Trump can’t or won’t win, just that it is less likely than Joe Biden winning. People are REALLY bad at probabilities. Trump is slightly more likely to win reelection than flipping a coin twice in a row and getting two heads. People when it comes to politics tend to look at probabilistic models and assume a 70% chance to win equates to a 70% share of the vote which is false. If a candidate was projected to get 70% of the vote they would be all but certain to win the presidency. There are good models out there. I like FiveThirtyEight who will give you an overview of the methodology they use to develop a probability of the two major candidates to win the Presidency. Trump currently sits at about a 1 and 3 chance of retaining office which is about the same as his chances as of election day 2016. If we make the math easy and say Trump's odds of election in 2016 were 1 in 3 and his odds in 2020 are 1 and 3 that would mean as of November 1st, 2016 Trump would have had a 1 in 9 chance of being a two-term president which is roughly 11%. Nobody gets surprised when something with an 11% chance of happening does. Look at it this way. The best hitters in baseball get hits roughly 1 in 3 plate appearances, but nobody is surprised when it happens. So if you want Trump to win consider it about as likely as a good baseball hitter getting a hit on any given AB.

I see this question has become a Trump cult meeting, so I`m going to interject for the sake of everyone`s sanity. I would vote for Joe Biden, without question. If he had run in 2016, he would have crushed Trump, though the death of his son is a pretty good reason not to run for president, so I understand. Biden might have some problems on the campaign trail, seeing how he is quite old and the Democrats seem to be trending in a younger direction, which I think is good. But, if he runs and gets the nomination, I`ll have a lot more faith in him than even some other Democrats, as he was a senator and VP. Trump just hasn`t done anything to give me faith in him. The guy is disrespectful, whether it`s to foreign leaders or to the military, doesn`t seem to know how government works, and thinks bullying people is the way to get people to do what he wants. That is not a healthy or constructive way to govern, and he is every stereotype of the ugly American. His tax cut did not go to the people who need it the most, and taxes will rise next year as the IRS adjusts for inflation. Other than that, Trump really has nothing he can take credit for other than trying to screw people out of healthcare. We need someone in office who is going to bat for all Americans, not just those who voted for him. We need someone who understands that for society and the American people to prosper, everyone needs to have affordable healthcare, relative job security, a living wage, and we need to get serious about climate change again. America does not live in its own world, and we can`t pretend we do; we will rot. Also, I confess it`s a little bit personal: I live overseas currently and was traveling for much of the last two years. All I hear about is Trump and what-about-this and why-is-it-like-this and I just want to be treated as a citizen of the world again, not some alien who crash-landed here. I hope other Democrats and liberals see it this way, and don`t sit on their hands because whoever is the nominee didn`t say that all transgender people are legally demigods or something.

There are also major substantive caveats to Mr. Trump’s fanfare. For all of the White House’s talk of historic Middle East peace deals, Israel was not in an actual state of conflict with either the United Arab Emirates or Bahrain. The countries are merely consecrating a quiet alliance that had been developing for years, noted Brian Katulis, a senior fellow at the liberal Center for American Progress, who said that Mr. Trump was like “the rooster taking credit for the dawn.”  Aaron David Miller, who worked on Middle East peace negotiating teams for several presidents, said the nominations paled in comparison with the accomplishments of past recipients: “When you look at other Nobel Prize winners in the Middle East, what you see are mostly larger-than-life — even heroic — figures who expended huge amounts of political capital and took risks on enterprises that were truly challenging.” He added, “Sadat and Rabin paid for their Nobels with their lives,” referring to the slain leaders of Egypt and Israel, Anwar Sadat and Yitzhak Rabin. When Mr. Trump hosted the leaders of Serbia and Kosovo this month to sign an agreement to normalize economic relations, a first step toward potentially friendly coexistence, the president’s son-in-law and adviser, Jared Kushner, declared it “a historic agreement” at a celebratory news conference. Christopher Hill, a former career U.S. diplomat who played a central role in the American-brokered 1995 Dayton Accords, which brought peace to neighboring Bosnia-Herzegovina, derided the Trump administration’s current efforts in the region as “McDiplomacy” lacking “the serious work” required to achieve lasting progress. The agreement also appears to have already run into trouble. It called for both Kosovo and Serbia to recognize Israel and open embassies in Jerusalem, with Israel returning the favor to Kosovo, which declared its independence from Serbia in 2008 and which Serbia does not recognize. But Israeli news reports say that Serbia is balking at Israeli recognition of Kosovo and will not open an embassy in Jerusalem after all if that happens. That threatens to unwind the entire agreement. The Balkans look easy by comparison to Afghanistan, where Mr. Trump is pursuing a comprehensive peace agreement to allow for a total withdrawal of American troops there. This doesn't cost Trump's campaign anything but helps get his message to voters. In addition to the Trump campaign, the Republican National Committee and several pro-Trump super PACs have planned heavy spending before Election Day. Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories. Sorry, Biden backers. President Donald Trump is not running out of campaign cash. Trump's overall reelection effort remains flush with cash with 53 days until Election Day, particularly when compared with where it stood around this time four years ago. His coffers remain full despite notable speed bumps, including big-dollar donors disappearing, an internal audit into questionable spending, and Republican handwringing in a recent New York Times article and other publications over Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden's recent financial surge. The Trump campaign ended July with more than $120 million, compared with about $99 million for Biden. For Trump, that's about three times more than the roughly $39 million his campaign reported at this point in 2016, an Insider review of Federal Election Commission records indicates. Similarly, the Republican National Committee ended July with about $110 million in reserve, compared with about $33 million for the Democratic National Committee. The RNC's stash is more than three times the $34.5 million it reported at the same point in August 2016. And while Biden's strong August fundraising has indeed diminished the Trump campaign's long-standing financial lead, neither campaign appears in jeopardy of running out of money, no matter how aggressive its 11th-hour spending gets, prominent Democrats and Republicans both acknowledged in interviews this week. Trump enters the BOK Center in Tulsa, Oklahoma on June 20. REUTERS/Leah Millis 'You can never have enough money' The Biden campaign and Democratic Party last week announced they together raised more than $360 million in August. The Trump campaign and Republican Party together said they raised about $210 million in August, significantly less than Biden but more than they ever had raised in a single month. Official figures for the full month of August, including cash-on-hand numbers going into September, are due to the FEC on September 20. "We are confident that we will have the resources we need," Republican National Committee spokesman Michael Ahrens told Insider. "It takes early investment and a lot of time to build a strong data operation and field program. The Democrats do not have either, and all the money in the world won't fix that." "You can never have enough money, and you always want more," said Matt Gorman, a vice president at Targeted Victory, a digital-marketing firm that works with numerous Republican campaigns. "But Trump, he doesn't need unlimited money to get in front of voters. The key is to spend it smart." Spending smart has been the clarion call of Trump's latest campaign manager, Bill Stepien, who usurped previous campaign manager Brad Parscale in July. Parscale is facing criticism — and even a federal complaint brought by the nonpartisan Campaign Legal Center — for his management of the Trump campaign's money. Ed Rollins, the chairman of the pro-Trump Great America super PAC, accused Parscale of spending like a "drunk sailor" in a New York Times story this week. The article also cited Trump campaign staffers expressing concerns about a "cash crunch" in the final weeks before the election after burning through its money on expensive Super Bowl ads, fundraising fees, pricey consultants, and other seemingly frivolous expenses. Under Stepien, Trump's campaign scaled back advertising among other expenses in August, relying heavily on the norm shattering, infomerciallike Republican National Convention and surrounding hoopla to fill the void until Labor Day, when it planned to boost spending. Trump also benefits from endless "earned media" — news coverage, punditry, and cable talk show chattering about his latest press conferences, pontifications, and tweets. This doesn't cost Trump's campaign anything, and Trump enjoys a decisive earned media advantage over Biden, according to an August study by marketing firm What If Media Group. In the campaign's final weeks, expect the Trump campaign to double down on its early spending in battleground states, such as executing a robust get-out-the-vote effort, said Rory McShane, a Republican political consultant whose firm works with several dozen GOP political committees. "They've prioritized field work, which is expensive. But Biden hasn't, and that's a Trump advantage," McShane said. Savings from COVID-19? But for the COVID-19 pandemic, Trump and Biden both would've been criss-crossing the country much more this year, likely staging an unending string of rallies and campaign events. Instead, both campaigns aren't spending as much money on some of the traditional trappings of a general election presidential campaign as they would in a United States free of an out-of-control deadly pandemic. Some areas of Trump campaign spending have even dropped from 2016 to 2020. For example, the campaign spent more than $666,000 on "event staging" in July 2016, while in July 2020, it spent about $230,000, according to FEC records. Even in the unlikely chance Trump's team blows through its reserves in a final scramble for four more years, it has a not-at-all secret weapon: Trump himself. During Election 2016, Trump fortified his campaign with more than $66 million of his own money. This time, Trump, who hasn't personally spent a dollar on his reelection bid, says he will if he must. It could come in the form of a loan or candidate contribution. But "we don't have to," Trump said Tuesday. Trump, as he did in 2016, could also launch a gimmicky campaign donation incentive promotion, where he contributed a dollar of his own cash for every dollar other people gave, up to a certain cap. Additionally, there are several super PACs actively promoting Trump and bashing Biden, largely via television and digital advertisements. America First Action, the most prominent of these super PACs, entered August with more than $26 million cash on hand. Like its super PAC brethren, American First Action is animated by the Supreme Court's 2010 Citizens United v. FEC decision and empowered to legally raise and spend unlimited amounts of money. A wealthy Trump donor wishing to give it a seven- or even eight-figure contribution between now and the election is free to do so. Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden's fundraising diminished the Trump campaign's long-standing financial lead, but neither campaign appears at risk of running out of money. REUTERS/Kevin Lamarque/File Photo Biden confident — and cautious Biden, too, benefits from a constellation of super PACs that play by Citizens United's same rules, including Priorities USA Action, Unite the Country, Democracy PAC, American Bridge 21st Century, and the LCV Victory Fund. While taking joy in the president's campaign's financial foibles and believing Biden will win, some Biden advocates acknowledge that Trump isn't about to go broke. "We've been outraising and outspending Trump's super PAC but our expectation is and always has been that Trump and his allies will have as much money as they need in this election," Priorities USA Action spokesperson Eliana Locke said. "Joe Biden is going to win because he's the better candidate, not because he can now spend more money." Added American Bridge 21st Century spokesman Max Steele: "As Democrats have made clear this entire cycle, no matter what the polls say or how much we raise, we will run like we're behind until every vote is counted." Biden campaign spokesperson Rosemary Boeglin said her team doesn't "take a single penny for granted" and will be "spending smartly and strategically to bring new voters into the Biden coalition and energize our broad base of support." Biden himself texted supporters Thursday afternoon to warn of the president's financial strength. "Trump is rapidly scaling up his campaign — raising tons of money and holding non-stop event," Biden wrote, before asking backers to "rush $12 to the campaign to help share our message with voters" during the next eight weeks.
